results.title: Black sickness, black cure (A)
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Holmes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Aboriginal health is notoriously bad, including high rates of alcoholism, infant mortality and leprosy, a disease which has almost disappeared from the western world. The program looks at ways the Aborigines are beginning to take control of their own health services, ultimately hoping to combine western medicine with their own bush remedies and holistic approach to the issue of health. Chris Masters reports on some of the initiatives, successful and unsuccessful, to blend the two.

results.title: The Shame (A)
results.creator_credit: Virginia Moncrieff and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This program discusses domestic violence and sexual abuse in the Aboriginal communities in regional and outback Australia, where Aboriginal women are fifteen times more likely to be hospitalised and ten times more likely to die from domestic assaults than their white counterparts. There is also a frighteningly high rate of sexual abuse of young Aboriginal children and as Patrick Dodson (Chairman, Reconciliation Council 1991-97) quite poignantly remarks “At stake is the survival of Aboriginal people”. Rather than laying blame, reporter Liz Jackson attempts to find out why domestic abuse is so prevalent and what, if anything, is being done to improve conditions for the Aboriginal communities. Unemployment, alcohol abuse, boredom, low self-esteem, and cultural rituals contribute, it would appear, to the Aboriginal male aggression towards their family, and particularly their wives. Through interviews and personal stories, “The Shame” provides an insight into this most disturbing and tragic situation which exists among the indigenous people of Australia.

results.title: Physical fitness
results.creator_credit: Richard Miner, Andrew Duffus and Walt Disney Educational Media Company
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fun to Be Fit Series”.
Animation and the singing of light-hearted lyrics contrasts the lack of physical activity since machinery has become such a large part of modern life, against the amount of physical activity that was necessary before the advent of such machinery. “We have a different style. But we don’t get enough exercise” are part of the lyrics which introduce this program. However, the video ends on a positive and hopeful note, as mankind is re-educated in the improvements possible to ensure health, happiness, and quality of life by increasing daily physical activities.

results.title: Waterholes : our turn
results.creator_credit: Kaye Munroe, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kaye Munroe remembers the day the devastating Gippsland bushfires came to her doorstep. The ‘travelling fingers’ of the bushfire threatened not only her home but the beauty of the area she loved. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with Latrobe City and Arts Victoria.

results.title: Why be physically fit?
results.creator_credit: Richard Miner and Walt Disney Educational Media Company
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fun to Be Fit Series”.
Adult-child roles are reversed as two children teach their physically unfit uncle the importance of being in good shape. This films shows students how being fit can help them have more energy, look better, feel better and cope with stress.

results.title: The Fundamentals of film making - No.2: using the camera
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Fundamentals of film making”.
An introduction to moving picture camera use; loading, running off leader and how to avoid fogging; how to keep the camera steady and use of a tripod; panning and common faults to avoid; the use of the zoom and the need for restraint; placing of the camera and avoidance of the jump cut; pitfalls of reverse action and parallax.
results.title_for_label: The Fundamentals of film making - No.2: using the camera
